												This is most likely one of the most dreariest and unhappiest games you will come across. And that is why I love it. Based on a short novel, this game is like a alternative version of the story which explores each character individually. In the original novel, they didn't have that much of a personality and the novel ends too quickly before you get to know them. Things I likeCharactersThey all have their unique personality and backstory, which are played out the more you explore each of their story chapters. You really do feel for these characters and their fates, and the game is filled with many heartbreaking scenes. There are also plenty of background characters that affects you emotionally, because you get to see so much suffering in this game.VoiceactingThe voices suits the characters perfectly and it's awesome that the original author, Harlan Ellison, voices the supercomputer AM. He does a fantastic job with the voiceacting. The only voice that was meh was Ted, I think the actor tries to hard to speak softly, which suits the character, but makes the acting seem very forced. Dire consequencesYou do have some choices, although they mostly lead to death, that you can choose throughout the story. It isn't like Telltale where it will shape the outcome, but it's interesting to see what happens.  I have to admit though, I laughed when they are sacrificing the poor woman and you can have Benny ask "Can I eat her?". StoryThere's no happy ending, there are no moments of joy you can celebrate in, because AM will quickly make sure the character suffers shortly after. You are faced with difficult topics of murder,♥♥♥♥♥♥ torture, suicide, cannibalism, human experiments, betrayal, abuse. I love the fact that this story dares to be this dreary. I can understand though why they removed the scene where  Benny is shown eating in infant. While only depicted in shadows, the scene is still disgustingly graphic. In the game, Benny will simply wonder where the baby is and he never eats it.Things I dislikedNo character interactionUnlike the novel, unfortunately, you never see the characters interact with each other. This is extremely unfortunate as there seemed to be a lot of character development going on between Ted and Ellen, but this never gets explored enough. You mostly see how Ted feels about her through his chapters, but nothing is shown from her point of view. Possible to get permanently stuck without continuationI am not sure if this is a fatal flaw in the design, or a deliberate thing. 												I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream is a bad game.This 1995 point and click adventure, incredibly loosely based off Harlan Ellison's 1967 short story and co-designed by Ellison himself, shows its age and not in the usual way, though not in a way that marks it as the bad game it is. Those particular reasons are timeless.Throughout the game, you're taken through five "psychodramas", which you can choose at your own leisure and each centering around a particular character with their own sordid history full of metaphor and mental allegory reminiscent of Psychonaut's own Dreamworlds (though obviously, this game came first), and an end sequence. There are a variety of actions you can complete in each scenario that either lowers or raises each character's "Spiritual Barometer", a basic morality system that, given the completely arbitrary and unsignposted actions that alter them, is thankfully nearly completely worthless on its own. The art design is fantastic, with the intentionally ugly humanoid sprites laid thickly on richly detailed backgrounds that range from rusting iron plates to cerebral nightmarescapes, to one incredibly memorable locale that invokes the late H R Giger's biomechnical designs. The animation is negligible, which is more than acceptable given the time period the game was made in and the memory constraints developers had to work with, but does its job well enough.Voice-acting and dialogue within I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream are executed very well, along with the noticeably good sound design in general, but have aged into campy and ridiculous conversations and reactions. Playing as a tortured girl having a mental breakdown from confronting her [Hymen Highwayman] shouldn't be funny, but when the [Hymen Highwayman] in question is a Saturday-morning cartoon villain and the follow up is a sassy one-liner accompanied by a hilarious uppercut it's impossible to take seriously. This permeates the entire game. AM doesn't sound like a malevolent god going steadily crazy inside his suffocating shell, he sounds like the Joker phoning in his lines after a particularly strong hangover. The entire script has fermented into a vassal of ham and stifled laughter. Only exceptions to this are Benny and Ted, the former who despite the massive overhaul to his character still comes across as a convincing racist military officer, and the latter whose entire storyline and character are just weak and forgettable. Despite the obviously unintentional retrospective of the narrative it's still enjoyable on its own.None of the above remotely contributes to why I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream is a bad game. At worst it'll make you sad that, if you played it like my own playthrough ended up, you won't leave this game with the sense that you have truly managed to appreciate Ellison's narrative and tackling of themes that are usually not even whispered about in videogames, but with a steaming sense of frustration, regret that you ever bothered with the game, and a throbbing headache from having to replay the same sections over and over because you didn't managed to abuse save-states as much as they obviously expected you to."Unsignposted Dead Ends". Innocuous actions which lock you into an unwinnable state, that the game does not notify you about or otherwise point out at all. You just wander around until your ever-decreasing cup of patience runs dry, trying to pick up another loose thread on the game's already obtuse and thoroughly unenjoyable puzzles, wondering if you're just missing a vital interaction or you have truly just screwed over your playthrough and you don't know how, when or why. One of the most hilarious examples had me complete an action that locked me into a dead state at the beginning of  a scenario, but still let me get through almost entirety of of the scenario anyway, only locking out the last ten seconds of puzzle before the ending. It happened an average of once per scenario, each necessitating a complete restart if you've saved at the wrong moment. Don't buy this game, folks, save your time, money, and the few non-aching brain cells you have left on something else. Anything else. It's not worth it.And the game was designed like this on purpose. Someone sat down, and decided that assuming you had to pour water on the electronics a second time due to dialogue, or giving the pliers to the wrong starving victim at the wrong moment, was going to lock you out of completing the game and they weren't going to do a damn thing about it, not even update that otherwise useless hint book of theirs. Why? I Have No Clue And I'm About To Scream.EDIT: As ridiculous and insulting as [Hymen Highwayman] is, Steam censors the alternative so they get the ridiculous and insulting name for a sexual assaulter, and their filter can blow me.

												I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream is a truly horrific and well made game based on Harlan Ellison's short story of the same name. It isn't fun, it isn't truly "winnable" as sometimes in life, there are only losing situations. It does some things wrong just as most point and click adventures did, like pixel hunting, but for everything it did wrong, it did so much right with the presentation. It is truly dark, depressing, disturbing, and sometimes downright offensive. And I love it so much.Story: Cogito ergo sum; I think, therefore I AMWithout getting into spoilers, a Cold War era computer, the Allied Mastercomputer, or AM for short, is created. AM is a sentient, self-aware computer who is filled with hatred for humanity and essentially ends up causing the absolute death and destruction of the entire human race, except for 5 people. He refrains from killing these 5 to take them to the center of the earth, extend their life span, and torture them. After being tortured for 109 years, they are given a message on a monolift from AM stating just how much he truly hates them and has a new game for them to play, and he created a mission for each of them. Their quests each have something to do with a fatal flaw of theirs which AM plans to use to his advantage to further break the  final humans. In other words... He's a huge ***hole in power. After blatently explaining to you via exposition why he feels hatred for each one of them, the "games" begin. You can choose your own order in which character to play as. The characters have been changed slightly from the original story (Which in fact IS included in the Bonus Content folder) but none are too annoyingly different. Most changes were made for gameplay purposes and probably because in the gaming industry, certain things are taboo.Presentation:The game's S.A.G.A. engine hasn't aged as well as the SCUMM engine it was based on, but it is still easy to navigate and a simple engine for the type of game IHNMAIMS is. Graphically, the game is both beautiful, and sometimes frightening depending on the story you are doing. The character art of each person on the bottom left of your GUI is well drawn and very detailed. Nimdok, one of the characters you play as for instance, is so detailed and well made that it is scary. He is... SO OLD! The only actual problems when it comes to visuals is a little bit of pixel hunting for specific items, but almost every 90's adventure game had that issue, and the character animations could have been better. Other than those two issues though, the game as well as the soundtrack is amazing and truly disturbing. Fits the story perfectly.I would definately recommend the game, but you shouldn't play if you are faint of heart or sensitive to some certain topics. Some of the 'triggers' in the game include mentions of the Holocaust, insanity, murder, suicide,♥♥♥♥♥♥ and paranoia, so if those things truly bug you, maybe you should avoid the game and the book as it may offend you.Extra Content:Original manual from 1996 release in PDF formatFull soundtrack by John Ottman consisting of 33 ingame songs with 21 bonus tracks in both MP3 and OGG formatThe original short story the game is based on in PDF formatThe Making of I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream in PDF format

												Do yourself a favor and don't buy this game.I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream was a '67 post-apocalyptic short story by Harlan Ellison that released to immense critical acclaim, garnering it a Hugo Award. Its dark dealings with the subjects of pure human sin and the struggle for redemption gave it an enduring legacy that lasts to this day; however, the same cannot be said of the piece of garbage that came out of it. Turns out Ellison eventually helped write and direct this game of the same name, released in '95. Unfortunately, the game renders Ellison's most basic themes unrecognizable and instead offers a laughable imitation of the actual story.While its overall atmosphere remains artfully crafted and deliciously gloomy, the game's graphics, point-and-click gameplay mechanics, and overall presentation have aged hideously - the game's "spooky" parts and cringe-worthy voice acting become just bad enough to be laughable at worst and just plain weird at best. It doesn't help that I Have No Mouth moves at a snail's pace; illogical "puzzles" hinder your progress in the game, and without a walkthrough to occasionally consult, it'll take you anywhere from 10 to 20 hours to complete the game.As an added insult, the plot of Harlan Ellison's original short story is made very difficult to comprehend due to some puzzling plot changes and multiple endings/storylines to worry about. Several bugs, glitches, and clunky/antiquated mechanics will make your playthrough even more miserable. It's a true shame that I Have No Mouth fails to capitalize on Ellison's cerebrally intense work in the successful way that it deserves to.Don't buy this unless you're just dying to see Ellison's writing represented in a different medium.A mediocre 5 spooks out of 10.

												Harlan Ellison is a weird guy.Now I've said that, I wouldn't be surprised if he turned up at my door at 3am demanding an explanation... but it's true. No "normal" mind could have come up with this scenario, but that's a good thing.Very loosely based on a short-story Ellison wrote back in the 60s, IHNMAIMS is a story about redemption, about bettering oneself, and about finding the goodness in everyone. I think.I'd be hesitant to call this a game in the usual sense, as it's full of red herrings, illogical puzzles (especially in the end-game scene) and sheer unfairness - it's more of an exploration into man's darkside. Dealing with mature themes such as♥♥♥♥♥♥ murder, suicide, one's sense of duty, paranoia and trust issues, IHNMAIMS is more of an exploration into deep psychological issues. Perhaps not in the sense of the "human condition" (as in, things that everybody faces at some point), but it is refreshing to have something that deals with these themes in a thoughtful, introspective manner - not just for mere shock value.I would have quite liked to see Benny as the original character from the story though. Perhaps in 1995 they felt they couldn't have a homosexual character struggling with his own identity and what it means in the wider scheme of things. Ellison had no problem back in 1967, so perhaps this means that literary types are better adjusted than gamers? Who knows. The game creators have mentioned in interviews they regret not exploring this angle, so I guess I'm not the only one.You'll probably need a walkthrough if you want to get the "good" ending, but IHNMAIMS is an absolutely fascinating game to play through. After hearing Ellison himself as the voice of AM, you can't imagine anybody else doing it.Now you'll have to excuse me. There's somebody at the door.

												Possibly worth it for the Nostalgia..I suspect that, in the mid nineties, this game got a lot of attention and attained a certain status because it's an adaptation of a short story that has a bit of a following, but really, it isn't that good.  I mean, taking into account that it's nearly 20 years old..and that the graphics / sound are going to be a bit limited, it still seems that it got more praise than it actually deserved.Don't get me wrong, I'm all for games that make you think, wonder and want to find out more but the story and challenges in IHNMAIMS really don't do that; they're not intriguing, just frustrating..and it gets worse as you go along.  How do I enter this other area that I need to do so to complete the game?  Well clearly you need to flush a toilet three times!  That must be so obvious as to not need any kind of hint or relevant dialogue.  Further on, I need to inspect this pixel clump with this recently found item (that was another hidden pixel clump) so I can solve the mystery that I didn't realise was a mystery.  Easy!  It's moon logic, but the bad sort.As I said, I can't really criticise the game for not using modern sound playback - this is mostly limited to parts that are voice acted, but, to be honest, I'd preferred if they'd saved those megabytes and kept to text.  Really, it goes between barely acceptable to cringingly awful.  The main antagonist (voiced by the actual author of the short story) is so bad as to be laughable, the only female character is a horrible stereotype who sounds like she's having *so* much fun.  The nazi doctor is just 'no' - I can only guess that there's a lack of germanic sounding people in the world.  The voice acting / scripting is so bad that I found myself just clicking through it as soon as I realised that it was something that I'd heard before, lest I gnaw my knuckles raw.Midi music was so badly done that I thought that I'd messed up my midi settings on my PC (I hadn't) and the much talked about 'dark themes' weren't dark at all for one of the characters..and for another were made so ridiculous as to have me giggling in serious scenes.  Lastly, I got stuck on some of the challenges, not because I hadn't worked out what needed to be done, but because I hadn't done things in the exact path that the game expected.  Seriously.  Either allow multiple paths to solutions and trigger off the next event or only allow one path.  Making it so that you have to reload an old save or somehow backtrack does not make for fun times.On the plus side, it's fairly cheap, it does actually work and it may encourage people to read so to find out why people were so excited about the game.  Oh, and it does come with the proper digital soundtrack, but just not in-game for some bizarre reason.

												Recommended, but not strongly. 												The most twisted game I've ever had the fortune of playing. Based off the short story (of the same name) by legendary writer, Harlan Ellison-- this is a dark point 'n' click adventure game.The writing is incredible-- again, the job has been done by Harlan, who chose to expand the story somewhat, giving the characters even more life. It's got fantastic emotive voice acting, with AM (the antagonist, a sadistic Allied supercomputer) voiced by Harlan Ellison himself. I felt for the characters (and they do go through hell-- specifically, their own personal hells), and you get quite a few to play with.You've got:1. Nimdok - ex-Nazi physician stuck in a concentration camp; forced to perform medical experiments on innocents to find 'the lost tribe'.2. Gorrister - man stuck in a zeppelin; suicidal over committing his wife to a mental institution; finds he is missing his heart.3. Ellen - ex-engineer stuck in an electronic pyramid, wall-to-wall of yellow (a colour she is afraid of); is given an opportunity to sabotage AM, but only if she can confront her yellow-clothed♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥inside the yellow elevator.4. Benny - ex-military captain who killed his squad, degenerated to a brutish simian who can't express his intelligent thoughts; stuck in a stone-age community that regularly performs human sacrifices to AM.5. Ted - paranoid schizophrenic stuck in a medieval castle; his love, Ellen (alluding to the other Ellen), is slowly dying because of a curse cast on her by her wicked stepmother.The gameplay goes beyond typical point 'n' click, featuring a revolutionary (for the time) morale system, where your actions and the choices you make dictates the outcome for the character. There are multiple endings, for each character, and for the endgame. Good and bad things can (and will) happen to the characters you controlled.One of the best games I've played, and also one of the best point 'n' clicks.

												Below is a short review on why I recommend the game, but if you would like to read more about the game, you can follow this link[lyonfacedblog.wordpress.com] to read a more fleshed out and relatively spoiler free review of the game as well as how it compares to the original short story the game is based on.------I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream is a story that is relatively timeless, and has many psychologically terrifying and does well to exploit our deep-seated fears as human beings. Each character's psyche and story is unique, and the mechanisms that lead you through each of their exploits, as well as the final chapter, serve to not only deepen the characteristics of each individual as well as the lore, but lets the player learn more about these inherent fears, and possibly even something about themselves.While the mechanics are fairly basic as well as the hidden "moral" system, it is still an enjoyable and interesting ride, especially considering the ability to have multiple endings. 												Most video games attack tough moral questions and present important life lessons with the grace, subtlety, and objectivity of a BET comic performing in Austin, Texas on the anniversary of September 11th. Ham-fisted political opinions draw you right out of a game, and just about any sort of perspective from the developer is only worthy of an eye-roll and a groan. This particular game is not of that variety.This game, based on the post-apocalyptic sci-fi short story by Harlan Ellison, is the paragon of point-and-click 90s adventure games. If you fondly reminisce about these kinds of games, you will not be disappointed. This is just about the perfect game you can purchase to satisfy your nostalgia kick. If you aren't familiar, this is the perfect way to introduce yourself to a piece of video game history. In this game, you play as five deep characters with different issues and personalities. To complete the game, you need to solve a series of problems they encounter in scenarios presented by the main antogonist, who you'll surely be introduced to soon enough. The puzzles require a sharp eye and creative mind to complete, with the endings entirely determined by how well you performed each chapter. Although some parts are not very intuitive, vigilance is key and well worth the effort.More important than the puzzles is the setting, which becomes an integral part of the story. Each character's setting is incredibly important to understanding the character themselves, and the effort put forth to creating such a deep game is apparent from minor details to the themes themselves. Some of the topics covered seem to have pretty obvious "correct opinions":♥♥♥♥♥♥is wrong, infidelity only leads to heartbreak, Dr. Mengele isn't someone you invite to your twins' birthday party, etc. With this comes important themes contingent throughout all stories, ranging from forgiveness to perseverance and chivalry. To appreciate all of the effort the developers and original author put into every intricate piece of the software, I would highly suggest taking your time and not rushing from one decision to the next. Carefully move forward, because like a lot of 90s games, this game will punish you for failure as harshly as it can.This game has a few minor flaws, and appeals to a certain demographic of players. These things can really turn some people off of a game entirely, but I would wager 75% of people who purchase this game will love it and 24% of people who purchase this game will at least appreciate the experience. It is worth every cent.

Ihose who like Sci Fi especially by Harlan Ellison would like this too as it's based on a short story of the same name by the same guy. Throughout the whole game, one points and clicks through several simulations for each of several characters which are essentially non linear levels. To beat the game you have to play them all successfully but in any order you like. The GUI and art are nice especially for the time. (Talk, Walk, Look, Use, Eat) I personally haven't noticed any game breaking glitches, it's well programmed imo. Each simulation delves deeply into the characters past. The object of the game, the way to escape, is basically to confront the characters demons and conclude the narrative. There is a small morality system in place where the games ending is affected by how well your character did dealing with their past and flaws. Or if you simply make a mistake in surviving the simulation itself you are transported back to your torture box. Sometimes these narratives approach disturbing topics like♥♥♥♥♥♥ genocide, human sacrifice. However I wouldn't say the game itself is particularly disturbing or scary, it has more of a sense of dread and whatever atmosphere the setting you are placed in creates atmosphere. The music and sound are okay. The voice acting is pretty good actually, but it does have it's hammy moments.The puzzles aren't really normal puzzles. They're more like symbolic puzzles. There's this sequence where you kill some animals, and have to wipe your hands clean before you can progress in Gorrister's simulation. One wouldn't immediately think of that, but from a narrative standpoint it totally makes sense. It definitely shows that Harlan Ellison wrote this game. This is a unique, moving experience with beautiful ascii graphics. Get it :)

And you might not think of performing an action again because you have already done so five times and it didn't work the first 5 times and the feedback given to you seems to indicate that it is simply not possible. I was forced to use a walkthrough on a number of occasions: one involved pixel-hunting and the two other occasions involved me saving the game after I had made irreversible choices without the game telling me I had lost the game. 												Below is a short review on why I recommend the game, but if you would like to read more about the game, you can follow this link[lyonfacedblog.wordpress.com] to read a more fleshed out and relatively spoiler free review of the game as well as how it compares to the original short story the game is based on.------I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream is a story that is relatively timeless, and has many psychologically terrifying and does well to exploit our deep-seated fears as human beings. Each character's psyche and story is unique, and the mechanisms that lead you through each of their exploits, as well as the final chapter, serve to not only deepen the characteristics of each individual as well as the lore, but lets the player learn more about these inherent fears, and possibly even something about themselves.While the mechanics are fairly basic as well as the hidden "moral" system, it is still an enjoyable and interesting ride, especially considering the ability to have multiple endings. The point-and-click genre of games is fairly known for having obtuse puzzles every now and then, and this one is no expection, but taking into account that the ultimate "good" ending in the game was suppose to virtually unreachable, it serves a purpose. The pixel graphics are still very well crafted, and the music and sound design are to be expected from this era.

												I'd heard about this game for a long time and now I've finally had the chance to play it. Put simply: it's awesome! Overall, if you haven't played this game, you should. No exceptions.

The game is a throw back to the 90's point n click adventure that we grew up on and love so much.Most likely you've not heard of this game before (like me) but its really well put together. its kinda choppy and kinda sloppy in some parts, but its redeeming qualities outweigh its flaws.  its very well written/scripted, although the puzzle elements are simple and reveal themselves fairly easily,not too too challenging as far as point n clicks go ( puzzles aren't super obtuse ) . The graphics are dated butclassic, and the animation is passable, nothing about the game felt like they " tried too hard " although the areasare small maybe 7 rooms within each scenario total, it limits the amount of pointless wandering that leaves you frustraited when you've felt you've exhausted all 'puzzle-item' combinations. if you get stuck you have a 'psychological profile' book in the inventory that gives you a blatantly obvious clueof what to do next.... BIG HINT on gameplay - Talk to the characters, (multiple times some times) to progress.on the negative side the game does have "game killing glitches " / unwinnable scenarios. The best way to Circumvent being perma-stuck is to keep a save file at the "Character Select Screen" and never overwrite that save. also Keep alternating Saves (or never overwrite a save) so you can go back before the error happened... ( like not talking with a key character / or using an item that removed it, when you still needed it for something else )also there are some actions you will have to perform repetatively, even though you know you are doing the taskcorrectly... But um Despite the flaws, its a REALLY cool game, i feel kinda sad i missed it growing up, but then i feelits cool because now i can appreciate an undiscovered authentic 90's gaming experience as an adult.

												I loved this game as a kid, and I love this game now. It's brilliantly written, and gorgeously messed up in it's own way. It's a point-and-click puzzle adventure, published in 1995, that explores the storylines of five people, all very different from the last. Everyone's storyline is fantastic, and I recommend them all. It doesn't take long to play through, but it's worth it the whole way.I will warn though, that this psychological thriller has very sensitive topics, such as insanity, paranoia,♥♥♥♥♥♥ and genocide. If it starts causing incredible discomfort, I would recommend stopping, and seeking emotional guidance, as it will likely only become worse.To anyone who does enjoy this game, I would also recommend reading Harlan Ellison's short story of the same title, first published in March of 1967. It's very well written, and very enjoyable to those interested in this sort of dark psychological literature.
